extent.note: 365 mm is in fact the maximum breadth observed. Folios in U1‒U3 are conspicuously smaller in breadth, as are folios at the end of U4. The folios have been resized on purpose (sometimes at the cost of truncating the original foliation, e.g., first folios in U3), so as to give the bundle a specific shape.

body.p: The Kācikāṇṭam, "The book of Kāci", that is Kāśī (Benares), is a Tamil version of the Kāśīkhaṇḍa of the late version of the Sanskrit Skandapurāṇa. The Kācikāṇṭam is the work of the Teṉkāci ("Southern Kāśī") king Ativīrarāmapāṇṭiyaṉ, who ruled in the second half of the 16th century. See Raghavan (1960, p. 235). On Ativīrarāmapāṇṭiyaṉ, best known for his Naiṭatam, a Tamil version of the Sanskrit Naiṣadha by Harṣa, see Shulman (2012, pp. 155ff.).
Other manuscript testimonies of this text are: Bnf Indien 332 and 334; GOML D. 565‒566 (see Rangacharya & Kuppusvami Sastri 1916, p. 549ff.).
The palm-leaf bundle, a single-text manuscript, contains, on the two woodcovers:
U2: 1 folio, unfoliated = title-page in Roman transcription and in French (f[1]r), by hand n° 1.
U3: 15 folios, Tamil foliation 2‒15 = title-page in Tamil (f[1]r) and table of contents. (f2r‒f11v, 4 to 5 lines per page), by hand n° 1. The foliation was possibly added in a second time.

U4: 267 folios, parallel Tamil foliation 1‒146, 148‒268 (no foliation 147) and Arabic foliation 1‒246 for Tamil foliated folios 1‒247, parallel Tamil foliation 1‒21 and Roman foliation I‒XXI, crossed-out in the first folios, for Tamil foliated folios 248‒268 = text (mūlam), by hand n° 2, in fact possibly several hands. 7 to 9 lines per page. The foliations were possibly added in a second time.

A paper leaf comes along with the bundle, with a text in French on the recto:
Mr Ducler, N° 37 intutule [i.e. intitulé] Casicandame, ou Histoire du Gange ou, Mythologie indienne, Depuis Naradeine ou Vischenou, jusqu’à Vitsouranadeine, (ouvrage anonyme) Contenant 290 Feuilles.
Paratexts: marginal benedictions, title-pages, invocation page, marginal chapter headers, in-text chapter completion statement, occasionally total stanzas, colophon.

U2, folio 1, recto, unfoliated = title-page: title, in big letters, in Roman transcription and in French.
Cafsy [i.e. Cassy] candame ou Histoire du Gange

U3, folio 1, recto, unfoliated = title-page: title, in big letters, in Tamil.
kācikāṇṭam

U4, folio 1, recto = invocation: marginal benedictions; 1 invocatory stanza (Kāppu), 2 aṭis per line.

Abbreviations. c = column, f = folio, lm = left margin, r = recto, rm = right margin, U = unit (codicological and/or textual), v = verso. GOML = Government Oriental Manuscripts Library, Madras/Chennai. MTL = Madras Tamil Lexicon. TMSSML = Tanjore Maharaja Serfoji Sarasvati Mahal Library.

Unmarked puḷḷi, ō, and ē restored. Conjectural (whether the text is not clearly legible or the character is ambigous, e.g. kāl or length of o and e) readings between parentheses. Alternative readings between parentheses separated by slash. Lost or entirely illegible character: "?". Crossed-out character: "X". Conjectural restoration of lost or entirely illegible between square brackets. Uppercase for initial vowels (in excerpts only). Unquoted text represented by (...). Conjunct letter: e.g. t°, to be read tum or tam. Grantha letters in bold. Symbols/Abbreviations made explicit, between curly brackets: {pcs} = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, short form; {pcl} = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, long form, that is, with long horizontal stroke towards right; {varuṣam}, {mācam}, {tēti}; {line-filler}. Unfoliated folio number between square brackets, e.g. "f[1]r". Numerals normalised to decimal notation, e.g. "1121" not "1000 1 100 2 10 1". Hyphen occasionaly used to mark in-word components. Hyphen systematically used at the end of a line when the line-beginning is within a word or within a cīr. Sandhi split to the minimum: overshort u occasionally restored as an apostrophe. Stanzas split by cīr, as far as possible. aṭi boundary marked by "‡".
